questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in which of the following conditions?


	HIV
	SLE
	CLL
	Hepatitis B
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis can be associated with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), and hepatitis B virus (HBV).

Causes of MPGN:

  • Primary MPGN: Idiopathic
  • Secondary Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) (typically type I) is more common in adults and occurs in the following conditions:
    • Chronic immune complex disorders, including SLE, hepatitis B and C infections (especially with cryoglobulinemia), endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses, HIV infection, and schistosomiasis.
    • α1-Antitrypsin deficiency.
    • Malignant diseases, particularly lymphoid tumours, like chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.

Pathology

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Immunofluorescence

Type I MPGN

Mesangial proliferative or membranoproliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening and Splitting.

(Double-contour or tram track appearance).

Subendothelial and mesangial deposits.

IgG ++ C3 (C1q ++ C4 may also present)

Type II MPGN (Dense Deposit Disease)

Dense intramembranous deposits.

C3; no C1q or C4

Membranous Nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening.

Subepithelial deposits.

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

Focal and segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis.

Effacement of foot processes; epithelial denudation.

Focal; IgM + C3 in many cases

questions.text: A patient with renal disease undergoes a biopsy. On Congo red staining, the deposits show apple-green birefringence under polarised light. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Amyloidosis:

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a patient with renal disease undergoing a biopsy and on Congo red staining, the deposits showing apple-green birefringence under polarized light points towards a diagnosis of AA amyloidosis, where chronic inflammation leads to the production of SAA, resulting in amyloid deposition in various organs.

The most appropriate staining technique for confirming the diagnosis in this patient is by Congo red stain.

Investigations in amyloidosis:

  • The diagnosis depends on the histologic demonstration of amyloid deposits in tissues.
  • The most common sites biopsied are the kidney when renal manifestations are present or rectal or gingival tissues in patients suspected of having systemic amyloidosis.
  • Examination of abdominal fat aspirates stained with Congo red can also be used for the diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis.
  • Staining:

Stains/technique

Appearance

Congo red
  • Most widely used and specific.
  • Light microscopy: Salmon pink/red stains.
  • Polarizing microscopy: Apple-green birefringence.

H & E
  • Eosin & hematoxylin staining on light microscopy.
  • Amorphous, eosinophilic, extracellular substance.

Thioflavin T
  • Fluorescent stain.
  • Yellow color under UV light.

Electron microscopy
  • Non-branching fibrils of indefinite length.
  • Diameter: 7.5-10 nm.

X-ray crystallography & infrared spectroscopy
  • Cross-β-pleated sheet conformation.

Methyl violet

Crystal violet

PAS
  • Amyloid positive.
  • Abdominal fat aspiration is preferred over rectal biopsy.
  • In suspected cases of AL amyloidosis, serum and urine protein electrophoresis and immunoelectrophoresis should be performed.
  • Bone marrow aspirates in such cases often show monoclonal plasmacytosis, even in the absence of overt multiple myeloma.
  • Scintigraphy with radiolabeled serum amyloid P component is a rapid and specific test since it binds to the amyloid deposits and reveals their presence.
  • It also gives a measure of the extent of amyloidosis and can be used to follow patients undergoing treatment.
  • The given images below show Congo red staining in amyloidosis.

Incorrect Options:

Minimal change disease (Option B): normal light microscopy; EM shows foot process effacement; Congo red negative.

Diabetic nephropathy (Option C): nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel–Wilson lesions); no Congo red positivity.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D): thickened GBM and subepithelial immune deposits; Congo red negative.

questions.text: Most characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy?
questions.solution:
CorrectOption A.

Kimmelstein Wilson disease: Kimmelstein Wilson disease, also known as Wilson's disease, is a genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in the body, primarily affecting the liver and brain. It is the most characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Diffuse glomerulosclerosis: Diffuse glomerulosclerosis refers to the widespread scarring and thickening of the glomeruli in the kidneys due to long-standing uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. This condition is a major cause of end-stage renal disease.

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is a distinct kidney disease characterized by scarring in specific areas of the glomeruli. While it can be associated with some forms of kidney damage, it is not the most characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy.

Option D. Armani Ebstein change: Armani Ebstein change is not a recognized term or characteristic finding related to diabetic nephropathy

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with solid cancer of the bowel. He also experienced massive proteinuria a few months after the initial diagnosis of cancer. What do you think is the likely cause of the development of urinary findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Membranous nephropathy

Explanation:

Characteristic Features of Membranous Nephropathy

Feature

Description

Primary Cause

Autoantibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) on podocytes (most common in idiopathic cases).

Secondary Causes

Autoimmune diseases (SLE), infections (Hepatitis B/C), drugs (NSAIDs, penicillamine), and malignancies (lung, breast, colon cancer).

Nephrotic Syndrome Features

Massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, oedema, hyperlipidemia, lipiduria.

Risk of Thrombosis

Renal vein thrombosis is a known complication.

Light Microscopy

Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) without hypercellularity.

Electron Microscopy (EM)

Subepithelial immune deposits create a "spike and dome" appearance.

Immunofluorescence

Granular IgG and C3 deposits along the GBM.

PLA2R Antibodies

Specific for primary membranous nephropathy and helps differentiate from secondary causes.

Treatment

ACE inhibitors/ARBs (reduce proteinuria), steroids + immunosuppressants (cyclophosphamide, rituximab) for severe cases.

Prognosis

⅓ spontaneous remission, ⅓ persistent proteinuria, ⅓ progress to ESRD.

 

 

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option B) (FSGS) is characterised by scarring and sclerosis of the glomeruli. While FSGS can occur in the setting of cancer, it is not commonly associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option C) (MPGN) is characterised by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and the proliferation of cells within the glomeruli.MPGN is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

Dense deposit disease (Option D), also known as C3 glomerulopathy, is characterised by the abnormal accumulation of complement component C3 within the glomeruli.Dense deposit disease is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Minimal change disease

Explanation:

  • Effacement of podocyte foot processes refers to the flattening or loss of the foot processes of podocytes, specialized cells located in the kidney's glomerulus. This structural change is a hallmark of minimal change disease (also called minimal change nephrotic syndrome).
  • It presents with severe proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and lipiduria. While the glomeruli appear normal under light microscopy, the characteristic finding of podocyte foot process effacement can only be observed under electron microscopy.
  • It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (2-6 years) and responds well to corticosteroid therapy.

Steroid-resistant glomerulonephritis (Option A) does not typically show effacement of podocyte foot processes. Instead, it may show more severe glomerular damage.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) (Option C) is marked by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is not typically associated with podocyte effacement.

Chronic glomerulonephritis (Option D) is associated with sclerosis and fibrosis in the glomeruli, and effacement of podocyte foot processes is not a characteristic finding.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents with complaints of hematuria. On examination, he is normotensive and has pedal edema. Investigations reveal that the patient has no glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. His renal biopsy finding is given below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anti-GBM antibodies

Explanation:

  • The presence of crescents on the renal biopsy & clinical presentation suggests rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
  • This condition can be caused by an anti-glomerular basement membrane (Anti-GBM). Anti-GBM antibodies are used to confirm the diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome, a form of RPGN.

 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

Type I RPGN

(Anti-GBM Ab-mediated)

Type II RPGN

(Immune complex-mediated)

Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Goodpasture syndrome

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  3. Lupus (SLE) nephritis
  4. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  5. IgA nephropathy

Includes:

  1. ANCA-associated
  2. Idiopathic
  3. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  4. Microscopic polyangiitis

IF finding:

Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3)
 

 

IF finding:

Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits)

 

IF finding:

No deposits

Electron microscopy: RPGN causes Rupture and wRinkling of GBM

 


Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) (Option A) are typically associated with systemic autoimmune diseases such as SLE. While SLE can cause glomerulonephritis and affect the kidneys, the presence of crescents on the renal biopsy suggests a more acute and rapidly progressive disease, making SLE a less likely diagnosis in this case.

HIV RNA (Option C): HIV infection can cause renal complications, including HIV-associated nephropathy, which is typically characterised by collapsing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) on renal biopsy. However, the patient’s presentation with hematuria, pedal oedema, and crescent formation on the renal biopsy makes Goodpasture syndrome (anti-GBM disease) a more likely diagnosis than HIV-associated nephropathy in this case.

Urine immunoelectrophoresis (Option D) detects monoclonal immunoglobulins in conditions like multiple myeloma and amyloidosis. However, the biopsy findings suggest Goodpasture syndrome, which is better diagnosed with tests such as anti-GBM antibodies.

questions.text: A female presents to the OPD with complaints of dysuria. Based on the microscopic examination, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – HSV:

The given image shows herpes simplex virus giant cells as they show:

  • Multinucleated
  • Moulding of nuclei
  • Margination of the nucleus

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not consistent with the microscopic examination findings.

questions.text: What type of urinary casts would you expect in a patient diagnosed with Fabry’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Maltese cross cast

Explanation:

  • Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by alpha-galactosidase A deficiency, leading to globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) accumulation in tissues, including the kidneys.
  • A characteristic finding in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also referred to as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts. These casts form when Gb3 precipitates within the renal tubules and appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when observed under polarized light.

Renal Cast Type

Condition Associated

Images

Hyaline casts

Normal conditions, Fever, Pregnancy

Muddy Brown casts

Acute tubular necrosis

Waxy casts

Chronic renal failure

Fatty casts

Nephrotic syndrome

RBC casts

Glomerulonephritis

WBC casts

Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis

Epithelial casts

Renal epithelial injury

Broad casts

Chronic renal disease

questions.text: What is the most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy, which is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kimmelstiel Wilson Nodules

Explanation:

  • Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules (aka Nodular glomerulosclerosis) are a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy.
  • They are ovoid or spherical, PAS-positive nodules found in the mesangial core of glomeruli.
  • They are often accompanied by mesangiolysis and sometimes surrounded by dilated capillary loops.

 

Armanni Ebstein change (Option B) refers to glycogen accumulation in renal tubular epithelial cells, seen in severe or poorly controlled diabetes, but it is not specific to diabetic nephropathy.

Aschoff nodule (Option C) is a histological hallmark of rheumatic fever, typically found in the myocardium.

Anitschkow cell (Option D) is a macrophage with a characteristic caterpillar-like nucleus, seen in rheumatic fever, not diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney?


	Most common primary renal malignancy
	Associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3
	Not associated with paraneoplastic syndrome
	The classic triad of flank pain, palpable mass, and hematuria is seen.
questions.solution:
Clear cell carcinoma is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, including hypercalcemia, erythrocytosis, and hypertension.

 

Clear cell carcinoma:

  • Prevalence: Accounts for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers. (Most common)
  • Tumour Characteristics: Composed of cells with clear or granular cytoplasm and a nonpapillary pattern.
  • Familial vs. Sporadic: Primarily sporadic (95%), but can also be familial.
  • Genetic Alterations:
    • Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3 in 98% of cases.
    • The VHL gene, located in this region, is a key tumour suppressor gene.
  • Classic triad of flank pain, palpable mass, and hematuria is commonly observed in kidney tumours, although it may not be present in all cases.
  • Morphology:
    • Origin: Arises from proximal tubular epithelium.
    • Gross Appearance:
      • Bright yellow-gray-white spherical masses.
      • Yellow colour due to lipid accumulation in tumour cells.
      • It may have areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and cystic regions.
  • Histopathology:
  • Most tumours are well-differentiated & some may show nuclear atypia, bizarre nuclei, and giant cells.
  • The growth pattern varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular (resembling tubules).
  • The tumour cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm containing glycogen and lipids.
  • The tumours have delicate branching vasculature and may show cystic and solid areas.

questions.text: Tamm-Horsfall protein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Renal casts

Explanation:

  • Tamm-Horsfall protein, produced in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle, is the most abundant protein in normal urine and serves as a marker of tubular function.
  • It plays a key role in preventing urinary tract infections and is the primary component of hyaline casts, the most common type of urinary casts.

Incorrect Options:

Mural thrombi (Option A) are blood clots that stick to the walls of blood vessels or the heart. They are not related to the Tamm-Horsfall protein, which is specific to renal tubular function and not involved in thrombus formation.

Curschmann spirals (Option B) are mucus plugs found in the sputum of patients with asthma or other obstructive pulmonary diseases.

Bence-Jones proteins (Option D) are free immunoglobulin light chains found in urine and are linked to multiple myeloma. Unlike the Tamm-Horsfall protein, which is a normal renal protein involved in renal casts, Bence-Jones proteins are abnormal products resulting from plasma cell malignancies.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with facial puffiness, frothy urine, hypertension, a history of hepatitis B infection, and microscopic hematuria. A kidney biopsy reveals a spike and dome pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Membranous Nephropathy

Explanation:

  • The combination of frothy urine, hypertension, and the biopsy finding points to the diagnosis of Membranous nephropathy, which is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is often associated with hepatitis B and is characterised by the spike and dome pattern on kidney biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposition (primarily IgG and C3).

Membranous Nephropathy:

  • M/C cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly patients.
  • It is immune complex-mediated and can be caused by malignancy (colon, lung, melanoma), infections(malaria, hepatitis B, C, syphilis, schistosomiasis), drugs (gold, penicillamine), or autoimmune conditions (SLE).

 

  • In primary membranous nephropathy, antibodies primarily target the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) located on the basal surface of podocytes. This triggers complement activation and subepithelial immune complex deposition, resembling Heymann nephritis lesions.
  • Other less common target antigens include THSD7A and neutral endopeptidase (CD10).
  • The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is crucial for diagnosing the disease.

Pathology

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Immunofluorescence

Membranous Nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Subepithelial deposits

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents with cola-coloured urine, high blood pressure, and periorbital oedema. Laboratory tests reveal a creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL, which rises to 4.5 mg/dL after 3 weeks despite treatment. What electron microscopic finding is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subepithelial deposits

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation, including cola-coloured urine, hypertension, edema, and rising creatinine levels, is highly suggestive of acute glomerulonephritis, particularly post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).
  • Subepithelial deposits are characteristic of PSGN in electron microscopy.

Pathological findings in PSGN

Grossly

Kidneys appear speckled or mottled due to numerous small haemorrhages (Flea-bitten appearance).

Light microscopy

Hypercellular glomeruli are caused by infiltration by leukocytes (neutrophils and monocytes) and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.

Electron microscope

‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane.

Immunofluorescence

Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Given the worsening renal function (rising creatinine levels) over time and the risk of progression to Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN), a finding of crescent formation (Option C) in the glomeruli would be expected, but it is a histopathological finding & not an electron microscope finding.

Subendothelial deposits (Option A) are typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), not in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Mesangial deposits (Option D) are often seen in conditions like IgA nephropathy, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), or diabetic nephropathy, but not typically in PSGN.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase in size on electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alpha 2 globulin

Explanation:

  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia, and the electrophoresis shows decreased albumin levels and increased levels of alpha-2 globulin.
  • The increase in alpha-2 globulin is due to an increase in macroglobulin, which is a larger protein, and its increase in the bloodstream serves as a compensatory mechanism in nephrotic syndrome to counteract the loss of albumin.

Gamma globulin (Option A) does not increase significantly. An increase in gamma globulins is seen in conditions like multiple myeloma or chronic inflammatory conditions, not in nephrotic syndrome.

Beta globulin (Option C) increases, but this increase is typically modest compared to the marked rise in alpha-2 globulins.

Albumin (Option D) is the major protein that decreases in size on electrophoresis in nephrotic syndrome due to its significant loss in the urine, leading to hypoalbuminemia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with 400 ml urine output per 24 hrs. On histology, he had RPGN with Pauci immune glomerulonephritis with crescents. What is the main etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ANCA

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of RPGN with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and crescents on histology strongly suggests an ANCA-associated vasculitis.
  • Pauci-immune means that there are few immune complexes present in the glomeruli, which is typical of ANCA-associated vasculitis.
  • ANCA are commonly associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s), microscopic polyangiitis, and Churg-Strauss syndrome, which can lead to pauci-immune RPGN.

 

Type I RPGN (Anti-GBM antibody-mediated)

Type II RPGN (Immune complex-mediated)

Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Goodpasture syndrome- the presence of Anti GBM. (Option A ruled out)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  3. Lupus (SLE) nephritis - ANA positive (Option D ruled out)
  4. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  5. IgA nephropathy

Includes:

  1. ANCA-associated
  2. Idiopathic
  3. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  4. Microscopic polyangiitis

IF finding:

Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3)

IF finding:

Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits)

IF finding:

No deposits

Electron microscopy: RPGN causes Rupture and wRinkling of GBM

 

 

Anti PLA2R (Option C) antibody is primarily associated with membranous nephropathy, which presents with nephrotic syndrome, not RPGN. The histological findings do not align with membranous nephropathy, which typically shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane without hypercellularity on light microscopy and a "spike and dome" appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 9-year-old boy who presents with hematuria, hypertension, facial puffiness for 3 days, and a recent history of throat infection two weeks ago, with urine examination showing albumin positivity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci:

  • This is the correct option. Group A streptococci, particularly Streptococcus pyogenes, are known to cause post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which can manifest with symptoms like hematuria, hypertension, and facial puffiness following a throat infection. It's a classic scenario for post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Group B beta-hemolytic streptococci: While Group B streptococci are associated with various infections, including neonatal sepsis and meningitis, they are not typically linked to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which is a more common presentation in the scenario described.

Option B - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium responsible for various infections, such as skin and soft tissue infections, but it is not a common cause of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Option D - Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a bacterium commonly associated with medical device-related infections and biofilm formation. It is not typically linked to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A patient presents with hematuria and flank pain. A renal mass is shown in the image provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma:

  • Chromophobe RCC has a distinct histological appearance, which shows plant cells, perinuclear halos, and raisinoid nuclei. It also shows positivity with Hale's colloidal iron stain and has a better prognosis compared to other RCC types.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D do not show plant cells.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cerebellar mass and a renal tumor, along with a similar family history. Which of the following is responsible for his findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – VHL:

  • VHL is associated with both clear cell RCC and cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not characterized by the presence of both renal tumor and cerebellar mass.

questions.text: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fabry’s disease:

  • Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or dysfunction of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A.
  • This leads to the accumulation of a lipid called globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) within various cells and tissues, including the kidneys.
  • One of the characteristic findings in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also known as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts.
  • These casts are formed by the precipitation of Gb3 within the renal tubules. They appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when viewed under polarized light.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are not associated with the presence of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

questions.text: Which of these is nephritic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Post-infectious glomerulonephritis:

  • Nephritic syndrome is characterized by glomerular inflammation and is associated with the following clinical features:
    • Hematuria
    • Proteinuria
    • Hypertension
    • Edema

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are nephrotic syndromes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Seminoma:

  • The image provided in the question is consistent with the histopathological appearance of a seminoma

  • Seminoma is a type of testicular germ cell tumor. It typically presents as a painless testicular mass or swelling.

  • Histologically, seminomas consist of uniform, undifferentiated germ cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nuclei. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Yolk-sac tumor: Yolk-sac tumor, also known as endodermal sinus tumor, is another type of testicular germ cell tumor. It primarily occurs in infants and young children. Histologically, yolk-sac tumors exhibit characteristic structures resembling primitive yolk sacs, such as Schiller-Duval bodies. The provided histopathology image does not show the features of a yolk-sac tumor.

Option C - Embryonal cell carcinoma: Embryonal cell carcinoma is another type of testicular germ cell tumor. It is composed of primitive, undifferentiated germ cells. Histologically, embryonal cell carcinomas often exhibit a mixture of different tissue types and can show features of glandular or tubular structures. The histopathology image provided does not demonstrate the characteristics of an embryonal cell carcinoma.

Option D - Teratoma: Teratoma is a type of testicular germ cell tumor that contains a variety of tissues derived from three embryonic germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm). Histologically, teratomas exhibit a diverse mixture of tissues, such as epithelial, mesenchymal, and neural elements. The provided histopathology image does not resemble the features of a teratoma.

questions.text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Painless hematuria:

  • Painless hematuria is the most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma.
  • Hematuria refers to the presence of blood in the urine, and when it occurs without pain, it is often associated with bladder carcinoma.
  • Painless hematuria may occur intermittently or be persistent, and it is an important warning sign that should prompt further evaluation for bladder cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Painful hematuria:

  • While hematuria can sometimes be associated with pain, especially in conditions such as urinary tract infections or kidney stones, painful hematuria is less commonly seen in bladder carcinoma.
  • Bladder carcinoma typically presents with painless hematuria as the primary symptom.

Option C - Dysuria:

  • Dysuria refers to painful or difficult urination and is not a consistent feature of bladder carcinoma.
  • Dysuria is more commonly associated with urinary tract infections.

Option D - Suprapubic mass:

  • The presence of a suprapubic mass is not a specific or consistent feature of bladder carcinoma.
  • Bladder carcinoma may lead to the development of a bladder tumor or a thickened bladder wall, but the presence of a palpable mass is less common.

questions.text: The most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy, which is shown below, is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kimmelstiel Wilson Nodules:

  • The most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy shown in the histopathological image is Kimmelstiel Wilson nodules.
  • These are pathognomonic lesions seen in the kidneys of patients with diabetic nephropathy.
  • They are characterized by the presence of nodular mesangial expansion, thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, and hyaline deposits.
  • These changes are indicative of advanced diabetic nephropathy and are associated with the development of proteinuria and progressive renal dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nephrotic Syndrome:

  • Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney disorder characterized by the abnormal leakage of proteins, particularly albumin, into the urine.
  • This results in hypoalbuminemia.
  • On serum electrophoresis, nephrotic syndrome can present with a characteristic pattern of decreased albumin levels and a prominent alpha-2 band.
  • The decreased albumin leads to a decrease in the albumin peak, and the alpha-2 band becomes more prominent relative to the albumin peak.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria. Looking at the immunofluorescence image below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lupus Nephritis:

  • Lupus nephritis is a kidney inflammation that occurs as a result of SLE.
  • The immunofluorescence findings in lupus nephritis demonstrate a variety of patterns, including the presence of a "full house" pattern.
  • This pattern shows granular deposits of IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, and C1q throughout the glomeruli.
  • The "full house" pattern indicates the deposition of immune complexes containing multiple types of antibodies and complement components.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS):

  • In FSGS, the immunofluorescence may not reveal any specific immune deposits or show only mild or nonspecific deposits.

Option B - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN):

  • In PSGN, the immunofluorescence findings show granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 along the glomerular basement membrane.
  • These immune deposits represent the immune complex deposition caused by the immune response to the streptococcal infection.

Option C - Good pasture syndrome:

  • The immunofluorescence findings in Good pasture syndrome reveal linear deposits of IgG along the GBM.
  • These linear deposits correspond to the binding of anti-GBM antibodies to the GBM.
